Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Examining Overlooked Issues in Wrongful Convictions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
It is well established that innocent persons sometimes are arrested and convicted for crimes they did not commit. It is also well established that in many of these wrongful conviction cases, the actual perpetrator went on to commit other crimes, including murders and rapes--crimes which may have been prevented if the wrong person had not been identified and the right person had been prosecuted. Although the exact definition of wrongful conviction and exoneration varies between sources, most scholars agree that the wrongful convictions that have been identified are the mere tip of a much larger iceberg, and likely represent a considerably larger body of cases involving the conviction of innocent persons. If this premise is correct, several limitations necessarily exist concerning our knowledge of the incidence of wrongful convictions, the factors that contribute to miscarriages of justice, and their consequences.

The overarching goal of the workshop is to advance wrongful conviction scholarship by enlisting theoretical perspectives and focusing on issues important to the administration of justice which have not garnered commensurate research attention. The workshop will bring together diverse scholars to discuss important topics that have largely been overlooked or ignored. These "elephants in the courtroom" in the study of wrongful convictions include: 1) the intersection of race and miscarriages of justice; 2) how and why guilty pleas, which account for the vast majority of convictions, contribute to miscarriages of justice; 3) wrongful convictions for misdemeanors, which account for roughly 80% of criminal charges; and 4) data needs and methodological constraints important to the scientific study of wrongful convictions and the effective dissemination of research findings for use by policymakers and practitioners. The specific objectives are: (1) To examine wrongful conviction issues that loom large but have not yet received sufficient attention by wrongful conviction scholars and policymakers; (2) To bring together scholars and professionals from varying disciplines (e.g., law, criminal justice, sociology, psychology, political science) to enhance understanding of wrongful convictions and to communicate new theories to test and methods to employ; and (3) To foster the translation of science into practice and policy by generating new programs of research into unexplored issues of wrongful conviction that could ultimately provide insight into the effectiveness and integrity of the criminal justice system. The workshop has the potential for broad impact through the achievement of desired societal outcomes (e.g., a reduction in wrongful convictions and correction of the corresponding problems caused when the truly guilty perpetrators remaining at large), fostering interdisciplinary collaborations, and the dissemination of resulting work products to academic and non-academic audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary purpose of this project was to advance the scholarship surrounding wrongful convictions, particularly on topics that have traditionally been understudied. To that end, a two-day workshop was held in October 2015. The workshop, “Elephants in the Courtroom: Examining Overlooked Issues in Wrongful Convictions,” involved academics, practitioners, and activists with varying levels of expertise in wrongful convictions and related topics. The goals of the workshop were: (1) To examine wrongful conviction issues that loom large but have yet to have received sufficient attention by wrongful conviction scholars and policymakers, specifically: (a) relationships between race and wrongful convictions; (b) guilty pleas and wrongful convictions; (c) wrongful misdemeanor convictions; and (d) data and methodological issues important to advance wrongful conviction research, scholarship, and policies; (2) To bring together scholars from varying disciplines to enhance understanding of wrongful convictions and consider novel theories to test and methods to employ; and (3) To foster the translation of science into practice and policy by generating new programs of research into unexplored issues of wrongful conviction that could ultimately provide insight into the effectiveness and integrity of the criminal justice system, as well as by disseminating via oral presentations and written publications the fruits of our discussions.

The goals of the workshop were achieved. First, the two-day workshop, attended by approximately 50 people, included four main sessions (corresponding with the four identified understudied topics), each of which had a moderator and three presenters and was followed by lively audience discussions. In addition, an ending capstone session was held to integrate what was learned in the previous sessions and to discuss next steps to continue the momentum of the workshop. Second, scholars from many disciplines were represented, including law, criminal justice, sociology, psychology, public policy, and political science. In addition to scholars, practitioners (police, prosecutors, judges, and defenders) and advocates (three Innocence projects) were present. Moreover, persons at varying stages of their career, including several doctoral students and early career professionals, were in attendance. Third, to foster the translation of science into practice, several tangible products emerged. One such product was a special issue of the Albany Law Review (vol. 79 no. 3 2015/2016) with the same theme of Elephants in the Courtroom, which included eight articles from workshop attendees (as well as three others from non-attendees). These articles are freely accessible at www.albanylawreview.org. Another product stemming from the workshop is the www.InnocenceResearch.org website, which provides a wealth of resources for academics and non-academics on wrongful conviction scholarship. (More information about the workshop itself can also be found at this website.) Finally, inspired by the workshop, attendees authored newspaper op-eds, blog and listserv posts, and presented at national conferences. A summary of the workshop and lessons learned is forthcoming in a special issue devoted to wrongful convictions in the practice-oriented National Institute of Justice Journal.

The intellectual merits gained from the workshop are many. Our primary objective was to advance the scholarship of wrongful conviction. We created an intimate atmosphere in which some of the best and brightest scholars talked seriously about what has been done (and has been done well), and what needs to be done. In the workshop, eminent scholars and junior scholars just starting on their career paths were asked to examine four important issues that have not been adequately addressed in the current wrongful conviction literature. The workshop also united scientists and scholars from varied disciplines and engaged them in conversations they typically do not have precisely because of the “silo-ed” nature of academic disciplines.

The workshop also had broad impacts on student training and education, and in policy and practice arenas. As reflected in our third objective, outcomes from the workshop were disseminated inside and outside of academic settings. Our dissemination efforts were strategically aimed at placing newly acquired knowledge and skills into the hands of researchers who already study wrongful conviction issues, as well as those who might be inspired to, but perhaps have not known where to begin. In addition, in aiming to translate knowledge into practice, the products (e.g., Albany Law Review and NIJ Journal articles, and innocenceresearch.org website) are available to policymakers and practitioners who work directly in criminal justice, thereby helping to ensure that they have the most up-to-date information about the science of wrongful convictions.
